subject: Force a restart of all the apache nodes during upgrade
commit_message:
Force a restart of all the apache nodes during upgrade

During the upgrades, the venv path will change and therefore the
apache configuration file will change too.

However we apply the restart of apache after the keystone_service_setup
for nodes [1:] (the first node gets restarted as first task of the
keystone_service_setup).

So during an upgrade, because apache is up, the configuration file has
changed but apache still serves the old code (because not restarted yet
on the nodes 1 and above) when the keystone_service_setup is applied.

The keystone module can then hit any node in the load balancer, which
could be a different version.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring apache is restarted and
therefore runs the latest code.

Change-Id: Iac94a8fc337c2139d1876b9753e46815910a0ba0
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk>

subject: ML2: Unify schema for binding normal and distributed ports
commit_message:
ML2: Unify schema for binding normal and distributed ports

Eliminates the ml2_dvr_port_bindings DB table and the duplicated code
that were added to ML2 to support DVR's distributed port bindings by
treating non-distributed port binding as a degenerate case of
distributed port binding.

This WIP patch is a step towards the goal described above. It
introduces a new ml2_port_binding_results DB table with a host field as
part of the primary key, and moves the vif_type and vif_details fields
from the existing ml2_port_bindings and ml2_dvr_port_bindings to this
new table.

An upcoming update to this patch will complete the schema
unification by moving the device_id and status fields from the
ml2_distributed_port_bindings table to the ml2_port_binding_results
table, eliminating the ml2_distributed_port_bindings_table altogether.
More logic cleanup will be possible once the DB schema is unified.

Deprecate the supported_pci_vendor_devs option in order to reduce
complexity for configuring SR-IOV. Currently, neutron validates the pci
vendor and product id. However this check is already done by the
nova-scheduler when it selects a suitable hypervisor. More precisely,

and updates the supported_pci_vendor_devs default to None.

any pci vendor validation. In case this option is set

commit_message:
(WIP)DVR: Add static routes to allow traffic directed at fixed_ip

When using DVR, if traffic is sent to the fixed IP of an
instance using the FIP gateway as the next-hop it is dropped
by the FIP gateway even when address scopes match.

The FIP gateway should act as a generic gateway to both
fixed IP's and floating IP's.

The FIP gateway should have routes to enable traffic to flow
directly to the fixed IP for matching address_scope subnets.

This fix checks for the address scopes when an interface is
added or removed to a router or when a gateway is set or cleared
and adds a static route in the fip namespace for the incoming
traffic.

This fix will enable BGP speakers to announce the FIP gateway
IP as the next-hop for each fixed IP host route accessible on
the given compute node.

subject: Non admin is not able to view all ports of shared network
commit_message:
Non admin is not able to view all ports of shared network

When a non admin executes port-list, all ports of shared network
should be visible. Currently ports created by non-admin are listed but
ports created by other tenants of shared network should also be listed.

This is needed to pick an IP address that is available and not allocated
so far while creating port by a non-admin.

The changes are in three areas.

1. In policy file, get_port now does not have any rules.
This is to ensure ports aer returned not only for admins and owners but
also other tenants.
2. _port_filer_hook does not filter on network tenant id.
This is to ensure all ports are now retrieved from database, not limiting
to networks of requester's tanant only.
3. get_ports now filters and ensures all rules are met to satisfy this bug's
requirement. Specially to list ports of other tenants of shared network.

Change-Id: I3c1300b5bfb1f82919d170e38a96e781a17eb515
Closes-Bug: 1587208

In Ansible 2.x the fact gathering process includes facts gathered
by facter [1] and ohai [2]if they are available. While this may be
useful in some environment, OpenStack-Ansible does not make use of

subject: SoftwareComponent hierarchy refactoring
commit_message:
SoftwareComponent hierarchy refactoring

Introduced a number of changes to classes of SoftwareComponent
hierarchy:

* BaseSoftwareComponent class removed, Installable and Configurable have
  no base anymore.

* Allowed number of failures may now be configured independently for
  different workflows.

* Allowed number of failures extended with 'two' and 'three'.

* Attribute usage for state persistence is simplified: attributes are
  now saved on appropriate servers and server groups.

* Inverted the names and semantics of status checking methods: they now
  return true if the needed status is already applied and no further
  action is needed.

* on%something% methods no longer trigger events, they have no default
  bodies at all, so it's easier to override them; events are triggered
  by the caller method.

* Handler methods got more arguments: besides the primary argument (a
  servergroup or a server) they get a list of pending servers, failed
  servers et.

* Some methods and method arguments renamed for consistency.

Change-Id: Ic52e66014d18e7fe640b79dd161286a1a9ebe15e

subject: Cache individual elasticsearch calls
commit_message:
Cache individual elasticsearch calls

When we introduced elastic-recheck querying to openstack-health we
started caching the entire api call whenever es was being queried on
the backend. At the time this made sense because there was a single
api call using elastic search so this was easier. But now that we have
multiple apis using elastic search data we should individually cache
the calls. There are 2 reasons for doing this:

1. We can share the cache of queries across api calls. We only use ES
to run e-r queries on failed runs. Even if looking at fialures from a
different view there will be a lot of overlap in what we're searching
for.

2. With the addition of failure lists that depend on a date range our
cache hit rate goes way down for the api call. That's because our
caching strategy is a bit naive still and doesn't understand ranges so
we always have a cache miss if one of the bounds on the range misses.
To mitigate this by caching ES queries the slow part of the query will
always be cached except for anything new.

commit_message:
Don't alarm users with "skipping postconfig" messages

On each overcloud deploy we printed a message like:

    endpoint map output

and in trunk with composable services we now print even more of
these. Such messages are slightly confusing because it looks like
something went wrong when in fact everything's fine. The fix is twofold:

   service entry and endpoints in Keystone for Horizon (after all it's
   not an API). We only used to create that endpoint because it was a
   requirement of Tuskar UI.
